ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The first half of this course covers a variety of topics, including DNA replication, transcription, translation, enzyme kinetics, and membranes. The second half of the course covers metabolic processes, starting with glycolysis and the citric acid cycle and ending with varied fatty acid metabolism, membrane components, single carbon units, photosynthesis, and amino acid synthesis.

I learned SO MUCH about biochemistry, beyond all the memorization. At first, I was so worried about this class, since biochem seems to be so daunting for pre-med students. However, Prof. Breaker and Engelman made it so accessible to us, and had no trouble re-explaining or stopping when we were confused.
I learned about the in-depth mechanisms and phenomenons of biochemistry.

- Biochemical foundations (proteins, amino acids, fatty acids, carbohydrates)
- Biochemical paradigms and how they play out in the body
Introduction to biochemical processes and metabolism
Some introduction into the basics of biochemistry, as well as a look at the mechanisms of metabolism.
So much was learned in this course but most importantly I learned how to manage a large amount of information and bettered my study habits
Learned more about combination of bio and chemistry
I learned that biochemistry is the basis for many sciences and needed when practicing medicine. I learned to combine my knowledge to answer broader questions
Learned a lot about biochem and orgo
I developed a strong foundation in biochemistry, along with a good understanding of several different biochemical mechanisms in detail (including photosynthesis, fatty acid metabolism, and more).
I learned more about how biochemical concepts apply to real-life scenarios.
intro biochem
I learned how to take amazing notes and use diagrams to understand mechanisms.
a lot of biochem knowledge
I learned so much about biochemistry and the different mechanisms that are important to keep the body functioning
Better understanding of biochemistry, ability to more critically think about science
Biochemistry topics bridging biology and organic chemistry.

This course presented a really good, clear introduction to biochemistry for anyone thinking about med school/grad school etc. The material is dense and typically not my favourite but I felt engaged with the course throughout
Lots of in-depth understanding of biochemical principles in preparation for the MCAT
more advanced principles of biochemistry and application of knowledge to novel scenarios

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A strength was the focus on foundational concepts and recurring themes as opposed to specific details like the mechanisms of individual reactions. This course really helps you connect all of the biological and chemical processes you learn in other courses (orgo made so much sense after taking this). The pace of the lectures was very reasonable, and having the lectures on Canvas to review was essential, I really hope STEM lectures continue to regularly record lectures in future semesters.  A weakness was the lack of practice questions presented before each exam, which made it hard to study for the first and third exams. Also, I did not like the inclusion of a TA-led lecture into the exam content for the final exam.

Strengths: Great organization with the lectures, passionate and kind professors, amazing TAs
Weaknesses: None.
The second half of the semester had a lot of topics that needed to be described more in-depth than what was covered for proper understanding of the material.

Strengths:
- Learn a lot
- Very supportive TA and instructors

Weaknesses:
- Not as much interactions with students
Strengths: very clear instruction by both professors, interesting content, wonderful teaching staff

I struggled a bit to stay engaged with the in depth focus on mechanisms of metabolism. I really appreciated when Professor Breaker put the mechanisms and steps of metabolism into broader context, and think that perhaps a bit more of this could help.
Great course. First test was unfair though
Lectures sometimes could be dry and lot of info was taught that we didnt need to know
Maybe we could have problem sets in addition to the exams to make sure we have understood what we have been taught
This course is very good and informative but it is a lot of information to process.

I liked that this course was split into two different parts between two very different professors -- when things are online on Zoom, it helps to shake things up a bit. I loved the emphasis on mechanisms. Slides were great, and exams were very reasonable and even interesting. But, I wish there were more assignments/problem sets/other ways to practice and learn concepts hands-on, and more simpler grades to even out the 4 exams.

A strength and weakness is that grading is based solely on 4 exams. Its a strength because theres not a lot of homework throughout the course, but its a weakness is that grades rely solely on 4 exams and theres no extra credit or way to make up for a bad exam.

Strengths - material was relatively well taught, clear; there was a focus on learning major concepts rather than specific details

Weaknesses - Sometimes it was unclear what material was expected for the exams; sometimes it was unclear what concepts were the important ones

Weaknesses- the content is very dense, professors are ok
Strengths- great TAs
the course was very organized

strengths: teaching team was very willing to answer questions!

weaknesses: very fast pace and we received a lot of technical information about mechanisms that we sometimes didn't need to know. this sometimes made certain parts of lecture very confusing

Strengths: Both professors excellent, lecture slides clear, tests fair 

Weaknesses: NA

The course material was super interesting. I really enjoyed the lectures and discussion sections. 

However, switching professors halfway through was pretty jarring. They had very different lecture styles, teaching styles, and testing styles.

I liked that the course was broken into four sections which seemed coherent and manageable amounts of information. At times it was difficult to know what the expectations were for exams  it would be helpful to have more guidance in the form of extra practice questions (more than just last years exam) since there was a lot of TMI information especially in the second half of the course.
This course is really challenging but was made bearable thanks to the work of the TAs being readily available. I'd give them more resources.

The lectures follow a logical format and are generally clear to understand. Some of the lectures (esp the unfamiliar material) seemed to go too quickly, but the lecture powerpoints themselves have ample writing so that students could learn the material on their own after class (thank you for that!). The Achilles heel of this class is that the final grade is based solely on exam performance. Therefore, it makes it difficult to know how solid of a grasp you have on the material until you are tested. Thus, the problem for studying becomes "I don't know which aspects of the course I don't understand." Having (1) a few problem sets, even if they're optional, or (2) posting multiple practice exams per midterm exam would aid studying tremendously.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Recorded lectures were excellent. No technical issues interfered with the class.
I think the live lectures that were also recorded was a huge benefit. I often put the professors at 0.75x speed and transcribed the lectures to really get some amazing notes.
Recorded lectures were great, as I was able to go back and watch things for which I did not fully understand the first time around
Recorded lectures were appreciated
I think one professor rather than 2 would be better
I really enjoyed the format

Online open book exams were really well done for virtual learning. Sections and review sessions especially were phenomenal, and the TAs did a great job at engaging and even making connections with the students despite being virtual. Lectures had very low turnout, but I don't think it's the professors' fault, since nobody wanted to show up live for a 9am.
Lectures were virtual, and I think that worked well.
Having lectures recorded was very helpful.
I really liked the live virtual sections
the most stressful part of this class was the timed exams!
Course was very well adjusted to COVID times
I appreciate that the exams were open note. However, the hour exams ended up feeling more like a race to see who can type the fastest than a reflection of my actual understanding of the material.
It seemed that the course wasnt changed much from pre-COVID Nandi think the setup would have worked equally in person.
Having all teaching staff readily available was key to success and should be a continued practice.
Overall, I think everything went smoothly. I didn't feel like the class was limited by online learning.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: You will probably take this course because it is a major or pre-med requirement, although if you plan on taking a lot of bio or chem classes you should also take biochem. If you're choosing between multiple biochem courses, the advantage of this one is that is has a low workload and the focus on exams forces you to really engage with and understand all of the material. Also, the emphasis on fundamental concepts, big ideas, and recurring themes is a plus.

Yes, absolutely. Although I don't know what this course looked like in-person, I'm sure that the professors and TAs were just as amazing. The professors for this class were SO amazing and passionate about biochemistry. They did everything in their power to help us learn, and the same with the TAs, especially Connor (absolute GOAT).
Only if you are specifically interested in the advanced metrics of biochemistry.
- Yes, because you will learn why the body works the way it does, and particularly how certain processes of the cell work the way they do. Plus, you probably have no choice either :)
I would recommend this course. The material was presented very clearly and the professors were always open to questions whether during the lectures or right after.
Yes
Most likely the people taking it are those that need it but my favorite pre med class
If its a requirement
I would recommend it since biochemistry is needed for most sciences and the way the lectures were thought was very clear
Yes absolutely

I would recommend if you're interested in biochemistry, and especially if you're planning on being pre-med. I think there's another biochem option, but I think this one is the better one? It wasn't painful at all and at times I actually quite enjoyed the class.
Yes, its a great class; you just have to stay on top of studying.
If you are interested in biochemistry, this is a pretty good basic introduction of the concepts
I would if you are willing to give the time
yes!
Yes, if you are interested in the mechanisms associated with biochemistry
Absolutely its a great and relatively painless way to learn biochemistry
Yes, the material was really interesting.

Yes. Count yourself lucky that you can take biochem with Prof Engelman and Prof Breaker. This is so much more manageable and well presented than biochem anywhere else, and I actually really enjoyed the material when it all started to come together at the end
If you have to take it.

Yes. The lectures follow a logical format and are generally easy to understand. The pace for some lectures (esp. the unfamiliar material) was sometimes too fast, but the lecture powerpoints themselves have ample notes so that students could learn the material on their own after class. The Achilles heel of this class is that the final grade is based solely on exam performance. Therefore, it makes it difficult to know how solid of a grasp you have on the material until you are tested. However, if you keep up with lectures (don't leave studying until the last minute!), the course is interesting and the grading is very fair.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture, recorded and posted on Canvas, with weekly section meetings
We also had live discussion sections with TAs and office hours with the professor each week.
Live virtual lecture
virtual section content review
- Weekly section with a TA, but not mandatory
The live virtual lectures were also recorded, which is how I completed the course.
Combo of recorded and live
Virtual discussion sections
N/A
Live lectures and recorded lectures
Lectures were also recorded
Live virtual lecture combined with live virtual discussion section
none
live section
live virtual lectures that were recorded!
I rewatched many of the recorded lectures.
Lecture was also recorded with small discussion sections recorded and live too
virtual discussion section
